data.title: Display a "First Editor Session" Dialog

milestone.title: v2.0
milestone.description: "Coming Soon" Stuff that would introduce too many or too severe breaking changes to be released in anything less than a major version step.

data.body:
Right now, there is no way to stumble across sample packages as a newbie.
- On the first startup of the editor, a "Welcome" dialog should ask whether the user would like to browse sample packages to install.
- If he chooses to, the Package Manager should open, switch to Online packages and filter by sample packages only.
- If he chooses not to, a menu option should be there to invoke this functionality later.
  - Probably add it to the Help menu on the upper right.

All of this can be implemented in the PackageManagerFrontend plugin.

data.title: Create more Sample Projects

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
As described [here](http://forum.adamslair.net/viewtopic.php?f=4&t=555), it would be a good idea to thoroughly test v2.0 by implementing some more sample projects.

---

**Note:** If you're contributing to this issue, the default should be to create your own, distinct sample repository, rather than working on the official one and creating Pull Requests. You can still release your sample packages using NuGet and they will show up in the Duality Package Manager / Sample Browser.

NuGet Docs: [here](https://docs.nuget.org/create)
Package Specs (Look at the `.Sample` ones): [here](https://github.com/AdamsLair/duality/tree/master/NuGetPackageSpecs)

**Note:** Sample Projects with more than 1 MB content size in total (Data directory) shouldn't go into the main repo at all, but into a distinct sample repo. As a general rule of thumb, a main repo sample ideally should stay below 500 KB to keep the history small. None of this applies for sample projects in distinct repositories - which is another reason why they should be preferred.

data.title: Write a v2.0 Project Upgrade Guide

milestone.title: v2.0
milestone.description: "Coming Soon" Stuff that would introduce too many or too severe breaking changes to be released in anything less than a major version step.

data.body:
Even though moving a project from v1.x to v2.0 isn't recommended or easy, it would be a good thing to get as much users as possible on the v2.0 boat soon, to prevent confusion like "Which version are you on?" and "Why does that API result in a compile error?". To achieve this, there should be an upgrade guide for existing projects.
- Warn users that it won't be easy or one-click-and-done, but still possible if some effort is acceptable.
- Explain the base procedure:
  - Make sure all game content is using the XML format.
  - Upgrade editor and dependency plugins to v2.0. If dependencies aren't available in v2.0 yet, wait until they are.
  - Install the v2.0 backend plugins.
  - Close the editor and keep it closed.
  - Upgrade the game plugin project.
    - Edit its .csproj file to be a PCL project.
    - Remove references to OpenTK and System.XY assemblies.
    - Add reference to DualityPrimitives.
    - Fix compile errors (renamed and moved classes, adjusted API).
    - Recompile!
  - Perform a text replace across all .res files with the provided list of renamed and relocated type names.
  - Open the editor and click on a few Resources. Have a look at the Log View. If there are errors, look out for type names that couldn't be resolved, close the editor and perform the replace step with them. Repeat until there are no more errors.
  - Delete and Re-Import all Fonts.

data.title: Create v2.0 NuGet Packages

milestone.title: v2.0
milestone.description: "Coming Soon" Stuff that would introduce too many or too severe breaking changes to be released in anything less than a major version step.

data.body:
- As the title says - for the upcoming release, all NuGet packages need to be updated with proper dependencies and updated semantic version numbers. 
  - A full set is required, including all core, editor and sample packages.
  - Package specs for backend plugins need to be created.
  - Backend plugins need to be added to the default plugin list to download.
- The final package setup needs to be tested locally, with a local repo.
  - Does a fresh install work?
  - From a v1.x version, does the package manager properly display warnings when trying to update? Is it clear that an update would introduce breaking changes and is likely not a good idea for an existing project without preparation?
  - When doing an update anyway, is the editor fully operable, so backend plugins can be installed later?

data.title: Hidden GameObjects and Components via Attribute

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body: As described [here](http://forum.adamslair.net/viewtopic.php?p=2875#p2875), users might want to hide certain objects from the Scene tree view and similar views. Consider implementing this.

data.title: Support Multi-File Resource Import

milestone.title: v2.0
milestone.description: "Coming Soon" Stuff that would introduce too many or too severe breaking changes to be released in anything less than a major version step.

data.body:
As stated [here](http://forum.adamslair.net/viewtopic.php?f=4&t=502), the current file import situation is less than ideal:
- It is impossible to import multiple source files at once in a single import operation. As a result, importers can only construct Resources from a single source file each.
- Copying a file to `Source/Media` automatically triggers an import. There are situations where this is not desired.
- Resources specify their source file in a Property for auto-reload in the editor. They can only react to a single file.
- The overall importer API is old and has grown organically. It might need a redesign.

Since there are many other important in the v2.0 milestone, this should **not** be resolved by creating a whole new asset management system, but instead be addressed with a reasonably low amount of changes.
### ToDo
- `Source/Media` should no longer trigger imports based on added files.
  - Instead, the Project View should trigger them based on incoming dragdrop operations of non-Resource files directly.
  - All the re-usable import logic should be located in the editors importer system, not the Project View.
  - Project View dragdrop should copy the files into the proper `Source/Media` directory first, then trigger the import operation.
- Resources should specify a list of source files if need be, rather than only a single one.
  - Changes in `Source/Media` should trigger re-import operations accordingly.
  - When looking for a Resource file to reload, make sure to use the recently introduced similar directory structure between `Data` and `Source/Media`.
- Importers should be able to use any amount of files from a single import operation and leave the rest to followup importers until all files have been used.
  - Unused files should spawn an error dialog as usual.

data.title: Add Screenshot Functionality

milestone.title: v2.0
milestone.description: "Coming Soon" Stuff that would introduce too many or too severe breaking changes to be released in anything less than a major version step.

data.body:
As stated [here](http://forum.adamslair.net/viewtopic.php?f=4&t=526), a built-in way to take screenshots would be nice, rather than manually setting up a RenderTarget. 
- This is trivial to implement when exposing a pixel data readback method to the graphics backend.
- Add it to the `IGraphicsBackend` directly.
- Similar API to the `INativeRenderTarget` readback.
- Can be implemented using `glReadPixels` in the default OpenTK backend.

data.title: Added Windows 10 friendly name
data.body:
Just a tip: Duality should be targeted for Windows 10 too, otherwise running Duality on Windows 10 makes it think it is running on a Windows 8 environment.

See https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/dn481241(v=vs.85).aspx

data.title: Fixed build on MonoDevelop
data.body: This shouldn't break anything since the output assemblies were not renamed.

data.title: Profile / Reconsider Component Update Model

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
In its current implementation, Components are updated per GameObject:
- Update Object A
  - Update Transform A
  - Update RigidBody A
  - ...
- Update Object B
  - Update Transform B
  - Update RigidBody B
  - ...
- ...

In order to pave the way for cache optimizations, this could be changed to the following:
- Update Transforms
  - Update Transform A
  - Update Transform B
  - ...
- Update RigidBodies
  - Update RigidBody A
  - Update RigidBody B
  - ...

This could potentially lead better performance for highly used Components such as Transform or RigidBody - but before changing anything, this needs to be profiled. Preferably off-site for a first eval.
- The old update model.
- The new update model.
- An optimized version of the new model, where each Component class instance only refers to an index in an external struct[] data container.

data.title: Keep an Eye on TypeInfo Serialization

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
[Making the Duality Core a PCL](https://github.com/AdamsLair/duality/issues/185) also requires switching from the old Type API to the [new TypeInfo API](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/dotnet/archive/2012/08/28/evolving-the-reflection-api.aspx). Unfortunately, Serialization will have a hard time coping with this, to the point that I would consider TypeInfo completely unsupported as a serializable type.
- The .Net Framework makes `TypeInfo` derive from `Type` in .Net 4.5, but Windows Store apps have `Type` derive from `object`, and `TypeInfo` directly from `MemberInfo`.
- At runtime in .Net 4.5, these are `RuntimeType` objects, which derive from `TypeInfo`, which derives from `Type`. Thus, the two classes are completely indistinguishable when serializing them, because `RuntimeType` is simply _both_ of them.
- When deserializing, a decision needs to be made which kind of object to retrieve - `TypeInfo` or `Type`. This choice is purely virtual in .Net 4.5, but distinctive in Windows Store apps. Choosing the wrong one will result in an error when attempting to assign the value to a field or array index.

This results in an erroneous deserialization of content, depending on whether the underlying platform implements Type as part of the TypeInfo inheritance or not. There is nothing Duality can do about this, because **there is no difference between the two for an object in the .Net 4.5 runtime**.

data.title: Disable SDL2 Support in OpenTK Editor Backend

milestone.title: v2.0
milestone.description: "Coming Soon" Stuff that would introduce too many or too severe breaking changes to be released in anything less than a major version step.

data.body:
`System.AccessViolationException was unhandled
Message: An unhandled exception of type 'System.AccessViolationException' occurred in OpenTK.dll
Additional information: Attempted to read or write protected memory. This is often an indication that other memory is corrupt.`

After downloading the packages, Duality Editor crashes on startup somewhere in `Sdl2GraphicsContext.cs` with the exception shown above. I'm trying to run it on Surface Pro 3, Win 8.1 Pro 64.

data.title: Prefab ChangeLists Always Clone

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
- When applying a PrefabLinks change list entries, the value of each entry is cloned before assigning it.
- This is correct for container classes and similar, but not for references.
- It works when the object in question is not the root value.
  - A `GameObject` property fails by copying the referenced GameObject.
  - A `List<GameObject>` property succeeds, because copying the list is correct and the cloning system automatically decides not to clone each GameObject reference inside.
- **Solution:** Let the cloning system decide how to handle the root object as well in this case. It clearly has a better idea of what to do than the current PrefabLink apply code.

data.title: Remove OpenTK from Plugins

milestone.title: v2.0
milestone.description: "Coming Soon" Stuff that would introduce too many or too severe breaking changes to be released in anything less than a major version step.

data.body:
As mentioned in the [main porting issue](https://github.com/AdamsLair/duality/issues/184), there should be an abstraction layer between Duality and OpenTK.
- As a first step, extend Duality so a core plugin will never need to reference OpenTK.
- Remove OpenTK references from all official core and editor plugins.

data.title: Provide a 1.x / 2.x Content Update Script

milestone.title: v2.0
milestone.description: "Coming Soon" Stuff that would introduce too many or too severe breaking changes to be released in anything less than a major version step.

data.body:
- Due to moving from OpenTK.VectorX to Duality.VectorX, all old content is unusable.
- SerializeErrorHandlers can't handle this, because
  - OpenTK.VectorX can still be resolved, so no error will trigger for this.
  - AssignFieldErrors can handle simple cases, but not arbitrarily complex ones like `List<Vector2[]>`
- Users can manually fix this by switching to XML serialization before updating and doing a manual string replace operation across all .res file.
- However, this is not a solution with great usability. There should be an automated way to handle this.

data.title: Remove System.Serializable References

milestone.title: v2.0
milestone.description: "Coming Soon" Stuff that would introduce too many or too severe breaking changes to be released in anything less than a major version step.

data.body:
If Duality shall become portable, the `Serializable` and `NonSerialized` attribute are in the way, because they are not available pretty much anywhere except in desktop .Net
- They do not provide any useful functionality except flagging metadata.
- They are used as the only external part of Duality serialization - without a good reason.
- There is no reason to use them in the first place, except that they're there.

They should be completely replaced by custom classes.
- `Duality.Serialized` will replace `System.Serializable`
- `Duality.DontSerialize` will replace `System.NonSerialized`

Although it would make sense to move them to the Duality.Serialization namespace, they shouldn't for accessibility reasons. Also consider moving the general-use cloning attributes (flags & behavior) out of there.

data.title: Cleanup Unused Classes

milestone.title: v2.0
milestone.description: "Coming Soon" Stuff that would introduce too many or too severe breaking changes to be released in anything less than a major version step.

data.body:
The v2.0 update is an ideal time to remove stuff. Find classes and systems that are largely unused and get rid of them.
## Candidates for Removal
- The whole Animation subsystem.
  - Not aware of anyone using it, didn't ever use it myself.
  - Feels a bit clumsy to programmers and is mostly useless to artists without editor support.
  - Extending it doesn't seem useful in the wake of far better systems like Spine.
- Certain very specialized MathF methods.
  - GetLinearPrediction, GetLinearPrediction2

data.title: Move Primitves to a Separate Project

milestone.title: v2.0
milestone.description: "Coming Soon" Stuff that would introduce too many or too severe breaking changes to be released in anything less than a major version step.

data.body:
In preparation for the abstraction layer between Duality and OpenTK, a set of basic data types should be moved from Duality to a separate dependency library, so it can be used by dependencies like Farseer and OpenTK.
- It should be a distinct NuGet package - but not a Duality package. Doesn't make sense to let users update this separately, the Package Manager should simply consider this a "part" of Duality using a hidden dependency. (Similar to how OpenTK and Farseer are handled)
- **Types that are qualified** to move there:
  1. Simple data structure definitions.
  2. Self-contained, no external requirements to "bigger" systems.
  3. Potentially useful to Duality dependencies.
  4. Very high stability in API and functionality.
  5. Classes that are required for the _communication between libraries_.
  6. General-purpose. Independent from specific use cases. 
- **Types to move** there:
  - `Vector2`, `Vector3`, `Vector4`
  - `ColorRgba`, `ColorHsva`, `IColorData`
  - [`[Serialized]`](https://github.com/AdamsLair/duality/issues/188), [`[DontSerialize]`](https://github.com/AdamsLair/duality/issues/188)
  - ~~`Rect`~~ (Removed because of `iii`, `iv` and `v`)
  - ~~`Range`~~ (Removed because of `iii`, `iv` and `v`)
  - ~~`MathF`~~ (Removed because of `iv`, `v` and `vi`)
  - ~~`RawList<T>`~~ (Removed, because of `iii` and `v`)
  - ~~`Grid<T>`~~ (Removed because of `iii` and `iv`)

data.title: Make Duality a Portable Class Library

milestone.title: v2.0
milestone.description: "Coming Soon" Stuff that would introduce too many or too severe breaking changes to be released in anything less than a major version step.

data.body:
In preparation for later cross-platform ports, Duality might need to lose some dependencies:
- For user plugins to be portable, they should be a PCL. 
- Since they depend on Duality, the core also needs to be a PCL.
- All direct, static dependencies need to be PCLs (~~OpenTK~~, Farseer, NVorbis)
- There is no System.Drawing. No Bitmap and Font classes!
  - Deal with Pixmap.LoadXY methods (which use Bitmaps to read image data from files)
  - Deal with Font loading (which uses system Fonts to render .ttf to a Pixmap them at runtime)
- There is no File I/O
  - Deal with anything that uses File or Directory classes. Potentially Path as well.
- There is no Serializable / NonSerialized stuff
  - Switch to a custom attribute?
- There is no Assembly.Load from file or byte[]

As an alternative, Duality could use the Bait-And-Switch method to provide a pseudo PCL layer and provide different core binaries for different platforms. If achievable, however, it would be preferable if the Duality core was an actual PCL and all platform-specifics could be moved to a plugin.

data.title: Introduce an OpenTK Abstraction Layer

milestone.title: v2.0
milestone.description: "Coming Soon" Stuff that would introduce too many or too severe breaking changes to be released in anything less than a major version step.

data.body:
For future multiplatform support and flexibility, there should be **no direct connection** between the Duality Core, Editor, Game or any of their Plugins and OpenTK. To achieve this, the following steps will be necessary:

("Move" means "Create an equivalent representation")
- Move Vector2/3/4 structures to Duality.
- Move publicly visible / relevant OpenTK enums to Duality.
- Create backend interfaces:
  - Common IDualityBackend base interface
    - Backend interfaces are not allowed to contain high-frequency methods in order to minimize the overhead of the additional interface and virtual method calls.
    - Backend GUID / Name
    - IsAvailable
    - Priority
    - Init / Terminate
